Award.AwardTitle: Developing Computer Science Pedagogical Content Knowledge through On-the-Job Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
WestEd proposes to study the Technical Education and Literacy in Schools (TEALS) program. TEALS, a pioneering work-place intervention of the non-profit Microsoft YouthSpark program, provides multi-year, on-the-job computer science education professional development to high school teachers. The project will identify an effective learning model to prepare in-service teachers to teach computer science. To ensure the model meets workplace requirements, all research will take place in an authentic high school learning context. In addition, the project will synthesize existing research on computer science education, integrate research with practice, and contribute to the development of theory around computer science pedagogy.

This project addresses a major barrier to increasing the number of qualified K-12 computer science teachers in the U.S. Few avenues currently exist for pre-service and in-service teachers to train in computer science pedagogy and become certified to teach computer science. As computer science is becoming increasingly important for many kinds of careers, improving teaching in this area is in the national interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When we began this project, the national movement to bring computer science (CS) to all students was still getting underway. The movement faced a major challenge: in order for all students to take CS courses, there needed to be a rapid increase in the number of computer science teachers. However, there were few professional development opportunities for people who wanted to become computer science teachers at the time.

The Technology Education and Literacy in Schools (TEALS) program presented an innovative solution: pair volunteer computer science industry professionals with existing high school teachers to launch new CS courses at their schools. Through a two-year co-teaching partnership, the classroom teachers would gain enough experience to teach the courses independently. This study of the TEALS co-teaching model was conducted over the course of three school years. We collected survey and assessment data from TEALS teachers and their students nationwide and conducted an in-depth case study of TEALS teachers in the San Francisco Bay Area.

Our original research questions and study design were focused on understanding this professional development model and the factors that make it successful, in terms of improving both teacher knowledge and student learning in CS. The goal was to generate insights about CS teacher preparation that could be applied outside of the TEALS program. The major accomplishments of the project are:

  • Developing a questionnaire to elicit CS teachers' pedagogical content knowledge (PCK). Pedagogical content knowledge is the specialized knowledge of a subject needed for teaching. This project created a 9-item open-ended questionnaire that asks teachers to reflect on a variety of CS teaching scenarios, including lesson planning and evaluating student work. The questionnaire was successful in eliciting responses that reflect a range of experiences and teaching approaches. This questionnaire is available for use by other researchers and teacher professional learning programs.

  • Developing a better understanding of how to support new CS teachers with co-teaching arrangements. We worked closely with eight high school teachers over the course of the project to understand how they improved their computer science teaching practice. Each school year, we visited teachers monthly to observe their lessons and examine their teaching knowledge development through surveys, interviews, and think-aloud activities. The case study analysis resulted in (a) a framework to explain several factors that influence computer science teaching knowledge in a co-teaching arrangement and (b) activities to draw out teachers' ideas about student understanding and pedagogical strategies.

    We saw that teachers expressed more ideas about student difficulties with specific subject topics than about teaching strategies to support student learning. We also learned that specific teaching tasks supported our participants in different ways depending on their level of knowledge and confidence with CS topics. Co-teaching with volunteers allowed new teachers of CS to concentrate on a subset of the instructional responsibilities and make space for learning new content and curriculum. Some instructional responsibilities are unique to CS teaching, such as code reviews. Support from co-teaching partners, who were CS professionals, enabled new teachers to better understand and execute these new responsibilities.

  • Tracking student learning and attitudes in TEALS classes over time. Achieving this goal proved to be challenging because there are no standardized assessments for high school computer science outside of the Advanced Placement (AP) exams. The project team first had to develop reliable assessments of student learning for TEALS's pre-AP introductory CS course and the TEALS AP Computer Science A course. Our analyses of the assessment data did not uncover a clear trend in students' scores for the TEALS pre-AP course. Student scores in the TEALS AP CS A course did improve from year to year. Student attitudes towards computer science were fairly stable throughout the study.

The teacher questionnaire and student learning assessments from this project have been shared with other research teams, broadening the range of methods researchers can use to measure and understand computer science education. Insights from this project have improved our understanding of computer science teaching knowledge, enabling us to better structure professional learning and support models for CS education.
